doc.title: Morgan Stanley | RESEARCH
doc.source_uri: 2025-08-31/China Economics August PMI Continued Growth SlowdownChina Economics August PMI Continued Growth Slowdown_2025-08-31

passages.text: Economic growth is weakening, with slowing goods and service consumption, slipping construction, and continued subdued new export orders. The 10bps uptick in manufacturing PMI was due to reduced weather disruptions on production (consensus: 20bps rise), but new orders remained steadily below 50. The rebound in service PMI (up 0.5pp to 50.5) was led by a seasonal uptick in summer travel services, but retail sales and property related services weakened. We thus maintain our 3Q real GDP tracking at \(\sim 4.5\% Y,\) and expect Sept. manufacturing PMI to stay \(70\) for two consecutive months.

Limited pass- through of upstream price gains: The anti- involution production controls in selected upstream sectors have led to continued commodity price increases (PMI input price index rising to a 10- month high of 53.3). But pass- through to mid- to- downstream sector remains limited given weak end- demand. Evident of this, PMI output price index stayed in contraction territory, at 49.1.

Outlook: We continue to expect real GDP growth to slip to \(4.5\% Y\) in 3Q on slower exports and reduced fiscal impulse, but market sentiment remains supported by liquidity and policy narrative. The 15th Five- Year plan to be announced at the 4th Plegium this mid- Oct should serve as a checkpoint on whether more meaning structural reforms would be carried out to ensure a durable anti- involution success.
